options.title: -A
options.description:
Display information about processes for all users, including those without
      controlling terminals.

options.title: -a
options.description:
Display information about processes for all users with controlling
      terminals.

options.title: -c
options.description:
Do not display full command with arguments, but only the executable name.
      This may be somewhat confusing; for example, all
      sh(1) scripts will show as
      “sh”.

options.title: -e
options.description: Display the environment as well.

options.title: -H
options.description: Also display information about kernel visible threads.

options.title: -h
options.description:
Repeat the information header as often as necessary to guarantee one
      header per page of information.

options.title: -j
options.description:
Print information associated with the following keywords: user, pid, ppid,
      pgid, sess, jobc, state, tt, time, and command.

options.title: -k
options.description: Also display information about kernel threads.

options.title: -L
options.description:
List the set of available keywords. This option should not be specified
      with other options.

options.title: -l
options.description:
Display information associated with the following keywords: uid, pid,
      ppid, cpu, pri, nice, vsz, rss, wchan, state, tt, time, and command.

options.title: -M core
options.description:
Extract values associated with the name list from the specified core
      instead of the running kernel.

options.title: -m
options.description: Sort by memory usage, instead of by start time ID.

options.title: -N system
options.description:
Extract the name list from the specified system instead of the running
      kernel.

options.title: -O fmt
options.description:
Add the information associated with the space or comma separated list of
      keywords specified, after the process ID, in the default information
      display. Keywords may be appended with an equals sign (‘=’)
      and a string. This causes the printed header to use the specified string
      instead of the standard header.

options.title: -o fmt
options.description:
Display information associated with the space or comma separated list of
      keywords specified. Keywords may be appended with an equals sign
      (‘=’) and a string. This causes the printed header to use
      the specified string instead of the standard header.

options.title: -p pid
options.description: Display information associated with the specified process ID.

options.title: -r
options.description: Sort by current CPU usage, instead of by start time ID.

options.title: -S
options.description:
Change the way the process time is calculated by summing all exited
      children to their parent process.

options.title: -T
options.description:
Display information about processes attached to the device associated with
      the standard input.

options.title: -t tty
options.description:
Display information about processes attached to the specified terminal
      device.

options.title: -U username
options.description:
Display the processes belonging to the specified
      username.

options.title: -u
options.description:
Display information associated with the following keywords: user, pid,
      %cpu, %mem, vsz, rss, tt, state, start, time, and command. The
      -u option implies the -r
      option.

options.title: -v
options.description:
Display information associated with the following keywords: pid, state,
      time, sl, re, pagein, vsz, rss, lim, tsiz, %cpu, %mem, and command. The
      -v option implies the -m
      option.

options.title: -W swap
options.description:
When not using the running kernel, extract swap information from the
      specified file.

options.title: -w
options.description:
Use 132 columns to display information, instead of the default, which is
      the window size. If the -w option is specified
      more than once, ps will use as many columns as
      necessary without regard for window size.

options.title: -x
options.description: Display information about processes without controlling terminals.
